thread.title: Tube strike: How do I get to Wimbledon?
thread.title_full: Tube strike: How do I get to Wimbledon? - Telegraph

author: Oliver Smith
title: Tube strike: How do I get to Wimbledon?
text: When will the Tube strike start? Transport for London (TfL) warns that there will be no Tube service from “late afternoon” on July 8 (customers are advised to complete their journey by 18:00, or to travel earlier if possible) – and no service at all on July 9. This does NOT include London Overground, DLR or tram services. See our complete Tube strike guide for more information . There will be no Tube service from “late afternoon” on July 8 Photo: GETTY How do I get to Wimbledon during the strike? Tube services will not run to or from Wimbledon, Southfields, or any other nearby Underground stations. The venue will still be accessible by bus, National Rail and tram services, but expect them to be far busier than usual. Rail Wimbledon mainline station is just over a mile from the All England Lawn Tennis Club, which is on Church Road (SW19 5AE). From here you can walk, take a taxi share, or board a shuttle bus to the venue. South West trains call at Waterloo, Vauxhall and Clapham Junction – where travellers can connect with Overground trains to and from stations such as Peckham Rye, Surrey Quays, Willesden Junction, Whitechapel and Highbury and Islington, as well as stations served by National Rail, such as Victoria, Shepherd’s Bush, Wembley Central and West Croydon. Thameslink services connect Wimbledon with stations across London, including Elephant and Castle, Blackfriars, St Pancras International, Kentish Town, West Hampstead and Tooting, then on to Luton via St Albans. Check TfL’s map for full details . Wimbledon station is just over a mile from the venue, Photo: GETTY Bus Local buses that stop close to the venue include the 493 (other stops include Tooting Broadway, Southfields and Richmond), the 39 (Putney Bridge and Battersea), the 693 (Battersea) and the 93 (Putney Bridge). A special bus service, operated by Go-Ahead London ( goaheadlondon.com ), runs between King’s Cross, Marble Arch and Victoria and the venue, at 30-minute intervals. Bike Additional space to park bikes at Wmbledon will be made available in Car Park 8 (entrance on Church Road opposite Gate 1), organisers have said. Or consider hiring a Boris bike – for a map of docking stations, see TfL's website . There will be extra space for cars and bikes Photo: GETTY Car “Additional space has been made available at The Championships Park and Ride at Morden Park (6.30am-11.00pm),” according to Wimbledon's says. “It can be accessed from the A3 at Tolworth and via the A240 and A24. The charge, for the public, is £15.00 per car and £20.00 for minibuses. On-day parking will also be available at Car Park 10, operated by the London Borough of Merton, on Wimbledon Park Road - £30 per car.” Tram Trams run every 10-15 minutes from East Croydon Station to Wimbledon. Further information TfL status updates are here and you can plan your alternative journey on public transport here . It also suggests following @TfLTravelAlerts on Twitter and signing up to its email updates . More information can be found on the Wimbledon website . Follow @telegraphtravel
